Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Genomic basis of desert adaptation in rodents
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed study focuses on genome-wide adaptation to an extreme environment, the aridity of desert ecosystems, across three rodent lineages. Understanding the evolutionary history of traits that allow organisms to adapt to their environments has long been a central goal of evolutionary biology. The project will contribute to recent medical, agricultural, and academic research that has been uncovering the genes responsible for complex adaptive traits and determining the effect mutations in these genes have on mice and other mammals, including humans. An especially important question is what is the extent of the "genetic toolbox": how many evolutionarily viable solutions are there to a common evolutionary problem, like thriving in an extreme environment? This project potentially will further our understanding of convergence at the molecular level and the repeatability of evolution. In addition, the investigators will engage in research with undergraduates from underrepresented groups and provide public and K12 outreach on this project.

Ultra-efficient kidneys are often associated with desert rodents who drink little to no free water. This study explores the genetic basis of three independent evolutionary origins of this trait. Transcriptomes will be sequenced for three pairs of species, one desert adapted and one temperate adapted, and sequence and expression data will be compared to answer: 1) is there convergence at the amino acid level in desert taxa not seen in the temperate taxa? 2) Are the same genes under selection in some or all of desert taxa? 3) Are there convergent gene expression patterns in the desert taxa not seen in the temperate taxa? The results from this research will provide essential insight into the way organisms adapt to their environment and how genomes evolve.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the genetic architecture of complex adaptive traits in natural populations and how they have arisen has long been a central goal in biology. Here, we focus on the unique adaptations in rodents associated with contending with life in an extreme environment, the desert, where low to seasonally-absent water enforce harsh selection pressures on its inhabitants. We studied this through two aims: 1) House mice (Mus musculus) have recently invaded the American desert southwest in the past few hundred years. How have they adapted to the desert and how has plasticity facilitated this adaptation over a relatively short timescale? 2) Across the order Rodentia, desert specialization has evolved multiple times. How much of this adaptation is convergent with respect to mutations, genes, and pathways across three families of interest?

 

To accomplish Aim 1, we measured water consumption, kidney morphology, serum solute levels, and kidney gene expression levels in captive populations of a putatively desert adapted population of Mus from Tucson, AZ, USA compared with a population from more mesic Edmonton, CA. We found multiple phenotypes associated with desert adaptation in the Tucson population. Further, to test whether plasticity may play a role in local adaptation, we removed access to water to mice from both populations for three days to test response to water stress and measured weight loss, serum solute levels, and kidney gene expression levels. We found that mice from the desert population responded less strongly to this stress, consistent with local adaptation. We also found that many of the genes that show evolved differences between the populations show plastic responses to water stress in the same direction in non-desert populations. This is consistent with plasticity facilitating adaptation in these populations. A manuscript for this work has been prepared to submission in Molecular Ecology.

To accomplish Aim 2, three rodent families that contain extreme desert specialists were identified and samples were collected from two species each (one desert adapted, one not desert adapted) to look for signals of convergent adaptive evolution at both the nucleotide level and the level of gene expression. Kidney transcriptomes were generated for each species as were gene expression profiles for multiple individuals. Work on this project is ongoing and will be prepared as a manuscript for submission to a peer-reviewed journal once completed.

The strength of these dual approaches allows us to look at evolution on two timescales, both within a species and between multiple familes, and ask about the extent of the genetic “toolbox,” that is how many evolutionarily viable solutions are there to the same evolutionary problem. The results from this work have been presented at academic conferences and shared with the general public through outreach activities associated with the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology at UC Berkeley.
